No, it isn't a DSLR with changeable lenses, but I didn't want one of those and didn't expect to get one in this price range.I wanted a camera that a) I can wear and use openly when traveling abroad, that isn't a huge target for theft, 2) isn't too heavy to wear around my neck for 8+ walking/biking/traveling hours at a time, and 3) which takes rechargeable AA batteries.This was perfect. Still getting used to all the modes/menu options and things I can do with it, as it is a big step up from my older Powershot---more megapixels, better zoom, better macro, special and photo editing effects, etc, but so far it has been fairly user friendly---and I am no professional photographer. More of a Luddite than a techie.Two cons:No viewfinder: you must use the large built-in screen in back to view/sight your shots8 frames per second shooting speed in sports/action mode might be too slow for some purposesTakes maximum 32 GB SDHC memory card, no higher and I cannot swap all my old memory cards from the old camera with this oneMany pros:Takes AA rechargeable photo batteries; means I'm always able to get fresh ones when traveling if need beCan use a standard battery charger and adaptor for use in my hotel room for those AA batteries (this is the same charger I use for other battery operated items we pack, like toothbrushes, a flashlight & kid toys)Lightweight, even with all 4 batteries inPriceGreat image quality/resolutionAll the pics I've taken so far today in normal, indoor lighting and partly cloudy outdoor lighting, have turned out great. No blur, no extra work setting anything up. I took pics of my kid (and kids basically never sit still) with no issues. Got up close and personal with some recent tulip and daffodil blooms in the garden, shot some selfies in a hallway mirror, in various natural and artificial light setups without changing a thing-- all were fine.Will put it through its paces noting the ups and downs, then will repost here if I come across any real dealbreakers or exciting new things to detail.

Reviews.Title: Don't buy. Have sent to be repaired twice after little use. Battery issues.Extremely poor customer service.
Reviews.Author: antiques4me
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera new in the box, sealed from someone who won it in a contest. Nothing but trouble from the git go. After two trips to the repair center after only taking 100 photos, I have concluded that the only batteries which work are made by Sony. WHY? Because they are slightly longer according to the guy at Batteries Plus who said they must be making better contact. Unfortunately neither rayovac, duracel nor energizer or any other AA batteries available at Batteries Plus are the same length. I tried it with rechargables, energizer and Ace batteries, none of which would consistently power the camera. How do you say LEMON in japanese? To make matters worse, when I complain to the repair center, they claim the camera is working perfectly. (It just doesn't work with any batteries available for sale at stores!) PS I have had two other sony cameras in the past, both with interior rechargeable batteries and they worked great. I never had a complaint before this one.

Reviews.Title: Pretty good
Reviews.Author: nighasingh73
Reviews.Content: For it's price it is a pretty decent camera, but one problem that I faced was you can't take picture if you are in a moving position! It will come out blurry!

Reviews.Title: Im happy whit it
Reviews.Author: Antonio
Reviews.Content: I need to learn more about photography so I believe this camera is good for the purpose and can help a lot

Reviews.Title: Nice Camera- poor delivery
Reviews.Author: Heidi Donahue
Reviews.Content: Great camera but the delivery was very sketchy. Fedex was supposed to deliver the package and I was tracking it. I went to check the tracking and it said "delivered" and I had no package. Fedex gave it to usps and usps decided to leave my camera in the entry hall to my apartment building....not even the lobby. Anyone could have stolen my camera. Amazon was supposed to help me with the problem and never contacted me back about my ordeal. I was fortunate enough to have a great super who had noticed it on the floor and decided to hand deliver it to me the next day.  Like I said before, great camera but I don't think I'll be buying from this company any more....or at least have the package sent to a different address so that I don't have to deal with usps.

Reviews.Title: Poor low light performance
Reviews.Author: BARRY C  RIES
Reviews.Content: I returned this camera as I was not happy with the pictures, I bought it to replace an older Sony Cybershot,  The older camera took much better pictures in low light situations.  So we will continue to use the old one.

Reviews.Title: Was an ok camera.
Reviews.Author: Quentin J Buffington
Reviews.Content: Ended up returning this camera, as the image quality was not the quite what I was hoping. Ended up purchasing a Canon EOS SL1 in its place. It powered up and was ready fast, good for up to about an 8x10 size print maybe an 11x14 if you used a low iso. Loved that it used AA batteries and would have kept it had I not needed something small and with better resolution.

Reviews.Title: Nice camera
Reviews.Author: Dennis Mareiro
Reviews.Content: This camera is easy to use and takes great pictures. Camera was delivered when promised and made a great present. thanks

Reviews.Title: Great Point and Shoot
Reviews.Author: B. George
Reviews.Content: This camera has everything I need in it, I love the effects setting where you can select a certain color to show in the picture while everything else is black and white. It also take smooth high quality pictures, and great optical zoom for far away shots. I recommend this camera if you love taking pictures.

Reviews.Title: Excellent choice for early photographer
Reviews.Author: Roy
Reviews.Content: Ease of use and quality of pictures have been the highlights of this purchase for granddaughter.  She is delighted with the camera.

Reviews.Title: What is not to like!
Reviews.Author: Lynn K. Luptak
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera for those who don't want to deal with switching lenses.  It takes excellent pictures and is much faster than my old Sony.  I take a lot of pictures of all our five shih tzus and birds so getting a fast shot is really important.  I also like the selections of shooting in different techniques.

Reviews.Title: orange tinge problem, but excellent outdoor camera
Reviews.Author: cabernhardt
Reviews.Content: Bought this camera for my wife. She's not to fond of it, and ended up buying a Nikon p520 (but she compares a $500 camera to $250 camera). The Sony has an orange tinge to indoor pictures, but it also depends on how crappy indoor lighting you have. I noticed that high intensity daylight bulbs help. Very bright outdoor pictures, and very sharp detail. It has lots of extra features in the settings like "toy mode", and its zoom is second to none. Overall if you have good indoor lighting and don't want to take a second mortgage than this may be the way to go.

Reviews.Title: Good Value
Reviews.Author: C. Trombly "C.T."
Reviews.Content: Good camera better than my cellphone. I'm not sure about the 20 megapixels. The pictures look good enough. One thing I did notice was indoors using the flash some pictures look washed out almost like the flash is too bright. All in all a good value zoom is okay. Its a little big for me im not a professional photographer so I didn't need a dslr but I still look like a tourist carrying this around

Reviews.Title: Glad I got this device
Reviews.Author: Lisa Inman
Reviews.Content: I am happy with this device and I am very pleased with the quality of the photo and the ease of use.

Reviews.Title: excellent product
Reviews.Author: Stephanie
Reviews.Content: very good dealI wanted a camera and I found this on sale at very good deal, it's just a semi professional camera for what I need, if you want something more out of this is the need prodcuto

Reviews.Title: excellent choice
Reviews.Author: scarlett
Reviews.Content: This camera is excellent, has various effect functions as a professional camera, it is easy to use, has 20mp, the camera design is very modern, I recommend it 100%, the photos are beautiful.

Reviews.Title: really loving this camera
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: This camera is what I was wanting the only thing I wish it showed you was how to get the shot stabilizer working because its not in the book or on the website.

Reviews.Title: Present for my son
Reviews.Author: ABEL CANTU
Reviews.Content: He is very happy with the camera he enjoyed taking pictures in the out door wild animals and school events.

Reviews.Title: Awesome!
Reviews.Author: Alyssa Padilla
Reviews.Content: The Camera is A Perfect Size, It's Also Very Lightweight, Has Many Great Features, And Takes Incredible Pictures. It Is Also Very Easy To Use.

Reviews.Title: My Cybershot is great!
Reviews.Author: DJ Tricky D
Reviews.Content: I have used this camera only a few times since I bought it but it has been the perfect complement to my Sony Video Camera.While am Recording with my video cam I can take some great still with my cyber Shot H200.And even though there are camera phones that deliver great pics nowadays... You still need to have a real camera to get the shots that you really want. This H200 is the camera to to just that.

Reviews.Title: Hello, Comparing with Sony Cyber-shot DCS-HX1 camera, it is lighter,with higher quality and long life battery.Thank you.
Reviews.Author: ahmadshah
Reviews.Content: Hello,Comparing with Sony Cyber-shot DCS-HX1 camera, it is lighter,with higher quality and long life battery.comparing the photos of both camera,it is more clearer.

Reviews.Title: Great upgrade
Reviews.Author: Doe
Reviews.Content: I'm very pleased with my purchase. It was exactly the kind of camera that I wanted, I needed an upgrade to my present digital camera and the Sony Cyber Shot fit the bill.

Reviews.Title: So far, so good!
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Bought this camera for my wife. It works well and my wife can actually use it OK. There are a lot of capabilities that are not being used by her but it seems simple to learn and understand. She likes the picture quality and options to do more sophisticated imaging.

Reviews.Title: very easy ti use
Reviews.Author: Luis
Reviews.Content: the unique problem was the battery are not rechargeable but it can solve it just buying them, the qualiy of the images are great!!

Reviews.Title: Great Product
Reviews.Author: Bryan
Reviews.Content: I gave this to my wife hoping she would like it. Its a little intimidating at first but when you go through the settings and see what it has to offer, its a great product. My wife is all over the place taking nice pictures. the quality could get her first place in the county fair. I would say that with the 20 megapixels and nice zoom, that anyone would love this camera

Reviews.Title: Sony Cyber H 200
Reviews.Author: JOHN
Reviews.Content: works good,you need time to get to know all of it's good or bad futures.Would not buy it again .

Reviews.Title: Fabulous and easy
Reviews.Author: Gypsy
Reviews.Content: Great camera for someone who is not the best at taking pictures. All my shots have come out clear and in focus. Can't wait to play around with this more.

Reviews.Title: Terrific camera
Reviews.Author: Ridge01
Reviews.Content: This camera is hard to beat.  It's a terrific value, very high quality, simple to use and takes great pictures.

Reviews.Title: Sony H200
Reviews.Author: dekattsmeow
Reviews.Content: Nice camera! Quick and easy to use but do wish it had a rechargeable lithium battery. Very clear photos, even with extreme close ups.

Reviews.Title: Nice Upgrade
Reviews.Author: David B.
Reviews.Content: This is a very nice 20 mega pixel camera, a nice upgrade from my old 12.1 mega pixel Sony CyberShot.

Reviews.Title: So far, so good
Reviews.Author: WPFLreviewer
Reviews.Content: I mainly got this camera for its ability to focus close-up. It does that with its "tracking focus" feature but I am not convinced this camera is getting any better pictures or close-ups than my iPhone 5. I'm pretty sure, however, that I'm going to sell my XSI and Tamron zoom lens because they are definitely redundant to this camera and the iPhone. I very much like the weight and size and ease of operation. I'm over the big digital cameras (and the XSI isn't even big), but for female hands I like this better. It's got tons of no-brainer shooting modes and you certainly can't complain about its zoom capabilities or the price considering all the features.Does anyone know if there's a lens cover that will fit this? One didn't come with it.

Reviews.Title: Feedback for my Sony DSC-H200
Reviews.Author: zbigniew las
Reviews.Content: Good product. Looks like the prfessional camera!  Easy to operate. Magnific fotos. Raly SONY product, not decive me! Good prise. Easy and correct transaction. Shipping at time. Thank you. I recomand everyone to bye it.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera To Work With.
Reviews.Author: Paul - Biloxi,MS
Reviews.Content: This is a really nice camera for the price. It has extra features like 21.6 megapixels and a longer zoom lens.

Reviews.Title: Good for the price
Reviews.Author: J. Plummer
Reviews.Content: This is the first Sony camera I have tried and I am still forming my opinion on it. My most recent camera before trying this was a Canon T3i. Comparing the two is a bit unfair as the T3i is much more expensive and has interchangable lenses. It is also much more customizable. I like the options of Program mode or manual for more experienced users. Using this camera straight out of the box was very unimpressive. After altering the settings it is possible to get some good quality photos from this camera. It is difficult to tell until you load them on your computer because the LCD is not great quality. The fact that this camera uses AA batteries is a very big plus too. Camera batteries can be very expensive and having a battery die can ruin your day as a photographer. Personally, I would recommend this camera if you are looking to spend under $200. For bit more you can get a Canon Powershot SX40 or SX50 which are much, much better in my opinion. For this price, this camera should be more than satisfactory if you are willing to adjust some of the settings.

Reviews.Title: Decent camera
Reviews.Author: Becky in NOLA "Becky"
Reviews.Content: The Sony DSC is a nice option between a phone camera and a DSLR. I got the camera on a Monday night and took it on vacation Tues morning, so my learning curve was out of the box, literally. I like the four batteries because I pretty much always forget to charge my battery pack and am out in the middle of nowhere with no ability to take pictures. With the four batteries I can run by a walmart or Bobby-Joe's fish, bait, and porn store and there will be batteries.The Sony took really good pictures for me on the default setting. I did find there was a distance to which facial features became lost. As you can see in the picture I uploaded of the alligator it does great in zoom, picking out the features of the reptile. The bird picture I took was of a bird in flight, still in default mode. Behind glass, shiny cars and planes in a museum, it took them all with ease.Taking a movie was as simple as moving the button to the movie option. Here, I overall liked the quality but it took awhile after zooming to refocus, maybe a good 5-6 seconds. So if I was shooting a movie and wanted to zoom quickly it wouldn't work.I love the scan feature, turn the knob/button to scan and the camera gives a menu to sort from. Faces with soft backgrounds, to pets, food, white scenes, blue scenes, fireworks, low light with tripod, it gives a great bunch of options for different scenes.I didn't find it bulky but I am using it after using my older Olympus and the size is about the same. It's a lot lighter than my six lb DSLR, which was nice when hiking around Avery island.There are a few negatives. If I turn it off with the lens cap on it sometimes makes me turn it off and on again, rather than letting me know the cap is on. The battery compartment is not easy to close, and for some unknown reason sony chose to put the memory card in the same compartment as the batteries. Yesterday I opened it to get the card to upload pictures to my computer and spilled the batteries everywhere. It's not a huge negative but just a weird inconvenient design feature.Overall I'm very happy with this camera and the pictures I took with it.

Reviews.Title: A camera of many compromises
Reviews.Author: Colin Brown "Colin Brown Microsoft MVP"
Reviews.Content: The Sony DSC-H200 is really a camera of many compromises.The first two things you will notice taking the Sony DSC-H200 out of the box are its size and its weight.  The camera is much larger than normal compact super zooms, roughly 2/3 the size of a full DSLR and its definately solidly built weighing quite a bit more than a standard compact.  The weight of the camera (560g including batteries compared to around 250g for a compact zoom) makes it harder to steady it when using high zoom and you will likely want to put the camera on a tripod (which really you should anyway when using high zooms).  There is built in image stabilisation however to offset camera shake to a degree.Included in the box you will get a removable lens cover, a small strap for the lens cover, a strap for the camera itself, four AA batteries and a small instruction manual as well as the actual camera itself.Personally I don't like the removable lens cap on these types of cameras. You can attach the small supplied strap to it and attach that to the camera body so that you don't lose the cover, however when taking photographs it just dangles there and gets annoying fairly quickly.  If you don't use the strap then you are in danger of potentially losing the lens cap.Strangely Sony have decided to use 4 AA batteries to power this camera rather than the normal rechargable Lithium-Ion type batteries found in most compacts. This in my opinion is a bit of a compromise. You never need to recharge the battery, simply insert more AA's and continue shooting however it's bulkier and costlier than the rechargeable type.  I would find it easier just to have a couple of extra small lithium-ion rechargeable batteries with me and swap out when required than being required to lug around a large pack of AAs.  Why a large pack of AAs?  Because this camera seems to go through batteries at a fairly rapid rate.  You only get roughly 320-360 pictures (depending on how much you use the zoom etc) on the four batteries before you need to swap them out.  If using the movie feature you get just over an hour before having change batteries.  In talking about batteries, the battery cover itself is a bit fiddly.  It's easy enough to open but closing the battery cover when you have batteries in it takes a little getting used to as the batteries are pushing up against the cover as you are trying to push it down and slide it closed whilst holding back the small cover lock lever.The camera will accept a variety of storage media including SD-Cards and Sony's own Memory sticks (I would recommend a class 10 or above SD-Card as these are cheap and fairly much standard nowadays). It also accepts Eye-Fi memory cards if you want to wirelessly upload your images to your computer or the internet.The camera itself sports one of the largest zooms I've seen going from 24mm (wide angle) to 633mm (full optical zoom).  This gives it a 26.4 times optical zoom which is really quite huge.  Most super zoom compacts nowadays are coming in at around the 20x optical zoom mark then enhancing that with digital zoom. Like all other cameras the Sony DSC-H200 also has a digital zoom extending it effectively to a whopping 1248mm (52x).  This isn't the largest combined zoom I've seen as I have a compact that does 64x (effectively 1600mm equivalent from its 25mm wide angle) but it should be more than enough to capture any distant object that you come across. The optical zoom is very impressive though and as you may know optical zooms are far better than digital (combined) zooms with regards to image quality.Given the size of the camera and the diameter of the lens (quite a bit larger standard compacts) I was quite disappointed to find that the size of the sensor was only 1/2.3" (6.17 x 4.55mm).  This is actually smaller than sensors found on most modern compacts (usually they are 1/2" 6.4 x 4.8mm).  Although its not the full story (as many other factors are involved such as sensor type etc), as a general rule of thumb you can say the larger the sensor the better the quality of images you will get (as an example, the sensor on one of my DSLR's is 22.3 x 14.9mm).Even with the slightly smaller sensor Sony has given this camera a whopping 20.1 megapixels (5184 x 2920 pixel).  Again this is larger than a lot of other cameras, especially in this price range (typically 16-18 megapixel) and should lead to more detailed/less grainy images (see below) and allow you to see more detail when you zoom in on a picture.  This again however appears to be a bit of a compromise by Sony, sensor size versus megapixel count.The LCD monitor on the back of the camera is the standard 3" 460,000 pixel found on most cameras. However in use it appears more grainy compared with other LCD monitors on other cameras.The shot mode wheel on the top of the camera appears to be fairly barren compared with other cameras as well, only offering you a choice of 6 modes compared to an average of 10 modes on others, however this is a bit deceiving as sony have given you multiple sub-modes within a each of these. Overall however the range of modes is still less than other compact super zooms in this price range.  These modes are basically pre-sets making taking quick shots easier.You can use the DSC-H200 anywhere from fully automatic, just point and shoot mode down to manual mode which allows you adjust a number of settings including ISO, shutter speed etc. Manual mode however is another of those compromises in that it doesn't offer you fully manual control of the camera, there is no manual focus for example.  There are however a few nice settings like the bracket shot mode which shoots 3 images at different exposures (you get a pre-determined choice for example 0.3EV, 0.7EV apart etc.), the ability to automatically shoot when a smile is detected on a person and continuous shot mode (keeps taking pictures as long as you hold down the shutter button).Other comprises are that the DSC-H200 only has an ISO setting up to 3200.  Whilst perfectly acceptable for most shots, most cameras now are giving you 6400 and 12800 ISO settings as well which the DSC-H200 doesn't.  Maximum shutter speed is also lacking compared with other cameras in this price range. The DSC-H200 gives you a maximum shutter speed of 1/1500 whilst most others are in the range of 1/2000 to 1/4000.  However the DSC-H200 makes up for this with quite a nice 30 second minimum shutter speed for long exposure pictures.One place the DSC-H200 does pick up some points is with it's flash. There is a small button on the front of the camera body to pop up the flash and the flash itself is very good, well above similar flashes on other compacts giving you a better lighting and range of shots without overexposing the images. When you are finished with the flash, just simply push it closed.On the back of the camera you have the fairly standard quick picks for self timer, flash on/off buttons on the wheel selector and the menu button to bring up more options for shots (e.g. adjust ISO etc.).One major annoyance with the DSC-H200 is the shot speed.  It takes a long time for the auto-focus to lock on (can be 2-3 seconds and sometimes more) and then it takes over a second to take the picture and store it onto your media card, ready to take another shot. Even in continuous shot mode, the DSC-H200 still only manages to take roughly 1 shot per second (after it has focused). I have managed to miss a few shots that I would have liked to get due to the length of time the DSC-H200 takes to get a picture.Another compromise Sony has taken is with the Video function of the camera.  The DSC-H200 will not shoot full hi-def 1080p movies, only 720p movies which seems quite odd given the specs of the camera.  Also there is no ability to adjust the frame rate. A lot of cameras now give you the ability to take slow motion movies (higher frame rates at the cost of size) which can be quite fun to use sometimes.Sound quality is a different story.  The DSC-H200 has multiple microphones built into the body which helps to greatly reduce ambient noise (you can however quite clearly hear the zoom motor if you use it) and it has quite a large microphone built into the top of the camera. Sound quality on video's is excellent.  It's just a shame Sony compromised the other aspects of shooting video.Picture quality is a bit on the grainy side which is slightly surprising given the 20.1 megapixel images it takes but for general holiday snaps you won't notice this and its perfectly acceptable for everyday use.Overall the Sony DSC-H200 is really well built and fits nicely in your hand when taking shots, if a bit on the heavy side. It has some nice features and specs (excellent optical zoom and high megapixel count) however these are offset by some of its other features (slightly grainy pictures, small sensor, only 720p video etc).  Although this is a fairly cheap camera it just lacks some of the features found in other cameras within a similar price bracket and it just feels Sony has made too many compromises with it.  Don't get me wrong, it's a perfectly fine camera but you can find better cameras out there for your money.Edit:  I have uploaded a couple of pictures to show the quality of images from the Sony DSC-H200.  The first image is a picture of the moon, taken in the evening with full digital zoom and the second is a quick snapshot (taken in easy mode) of a groundhog I noticed outside the back of my house.

Reviews.Title: Very good bridge camera
Reviews.Author: Iron Man "JON"
Reviews.Content: For those shutterbugs that are caught in the middle (upgrades from a compact but falls short of acquiring a DSLR), the Sony DSC-H200 Digital Camera with 3-Inch LCD fits the bill nicely. This camera's functionality is not at all hard to to familiarize. Although the Sony DSC-H200 would certainly not be a first choice for me as far as bridge camera's are concerned, having the chance to own one and compare it to my personal bridge camera in the same category which is Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ28k is where I will be basing this review. I am not a pro but my photographic skills are beyond the novice level. I have 2 bridge cameras (both Panasonic Lumix models FZ50k and FZ28k), a Nikon D3100 DSLR and one compact(Samsung ST100) that serves as a back up.At first glance, the Sony DSC-H200 Digital Camera looks modern and stylish. The curvature of the camera fits my hand in a secure fashion. The grips are made in such a way that unless you totally let go, it will not slip while you are grasping the camera. And since this camera does not have a viewfinder, it is where this curvature plays a major role. For the DSC-H200, Sony deviates from its usual norm of having Carl Zeiss lenses. It is now equipped with a Sony-branded aspherical 12-element lens with an amazing 26x optical zoom and a 2-way active mode image stabilization. With a zoom and image stabilization like this, you can take breath-taking close up shots with minimal shake that compensates for vertical and horizontal motion that is usually present in high zoom shots. The image stabilization worked great when I tried to focus on a boat by the lake and took a shot at the full 26x optical zoom. Just when I tought that the Lumix FZ28k has an outstanding 18x optical zoom, the DSC-H200 surpassed this with an amazing 26x optical zoom. The boat was a few miles away but the image seems to be just a few feet away. The lens also pulls back to a nifty 22.3mm (in 35mmm equivalent) where you can truly have wide angle shots. This is wider than my FZ28k which is set at 28mm. Where other bridge camera's image stabilization is electronic, the DSC-H200 stands out with its Optical IS. The resolution on the DSC-H200 is pushed up to an astounding 20.1MP. This is one of the highest is this class. Creating blow-ups with a 20.1MP resolution brings out stunning details on your pictures.Functionality is very user friendly. The controls, especially the mode dial are pretty much standard for bridge cameras. So if you currently own one, you will have minimal difficulty trying to set the dial or manipulate the controls to your desired mode. The video feature is great enabling you to take HD 720p resolution videos at 30 fps in MP4 format. My Lumix takes videos in the same 720p HD resolution in the same frame speed. Unlike the Lumix which is powered by a proprietary Li-Ion battery, the DSC-H200 is powered by 4 regular or rechargeable AA batteries. Note however that with rechargeables, your ability to avoid lag time increases and video times are short since unlike regular batteries, rechargeables looses the power hold even while not in use.The DSC-H200 expands its interface versatility by using both Memory Stick and the SD/SDHC format of memory cards. Again this is a deviation for Sony since previous camera models are strictly compatible only with their proprietary Memory Stick. This is a nice attraction for photographers since the SD/SDHC format is more widely used than the Memory Stick.Another great feature worth noting is the In-Camera Editing. The DCS-H200 has the ability to perform basic photo editing like Retouch, Trimming, Unsharping. You can now post or transfer edited photos to your PC.ISO sensitivity ratings goes up to 3200 but taking low light pictures past the 400 mark, I noticed a lot of noise. And no amount of adjustment seems to reduce the noise. It does take superb, sharp pictures with proper lighting. Using this on a clear day, produces outstanding results. Control configurations are adequate. Once it is in your grip, it's not hard to reach and manipulate buttons and dials.After all that's said and done, this camera is geared for the consumer with less aptitude towards creative photography. The absence of a viewfinder can attest to that fact. For more endearing photographic objectives, the DSC-H200 can hold its own but I still would not part with my full function DSLR. The Sony DSC-H200 would however, be a great back for those less demanding photographic objectives. I still give it a 5-star for its huge 26x Optical Zoom and its 20.1MP resolution. Very hard to overlook these great features at such a small configuration.

Reviews.Content: The rating would have been higher but I was not thrilled with the audio quality in video mode. Camera takes great pics.

Reviews.Title: Great little starter camera
Reviews.Author: Adam
Reviews.Content: Let me start off by saying - trying to be succinct with a digital camera review is difficult. There are so many features and functions available that one could easily type a novel without trying. That said, I will do my best.The Sony Cybershot H200 does a good job of giving the user enough control to get creative, without burdening them with too many technical details. This will either make the user happy that most of the guesswork is taken out of the equation, or leave them wanting more control than the camera can give them.At a tad over 20 megapixels, the images the camera capture are clean when the ISO is set low. The dynamic range in the images is pretty good. There are plenty of settings to enable the user to capture some of the most popular types of images - in-focus foreground subjects with background that are blown out, landscape images, low-light scenes, images which focus on skin tone, and a number of other settings that can be set with a simple twist of the dial and a couple of clicks with the selector switch on the back.Speaking of the back, the LCD is a nice touch. It's big and bright, and people should have no trouble seeing their way around the camera's menus thanks to it. The menus are intuitive, and there's even on-screen help that can assist you with everything from the basics to more advanced techniques.The on-board flash is powerful enough to rescue scenes which are too dark, but unfortunately there is no hot shoe, so adding on to the camera with external flashes and accessories is a no-go. The grip on the unit is a little aggressive for my taste, but it's not to the point of being uncomfortable.One of the things I found puzzling is that the camera has a manual mode. Traditionally this setting gives the user full control over aperture, shutter speed, ISO, white balance and focus. Most of those are there, but curiously manually focusing the lens seems to not be one of these options. Being one of the key components for taking a picture, it's sorely missing.Video capture seems to work adequately, and records at 720p. There is a connector for a mini-USB plug that supplies audio and video signal. Another drawback is there's no way to externally power the unit, nor is there a microphone input. You're stuck with what's on the camera when it comes to all of this.I think for its price it's a great bargain, and should be especially attractive to new shooters.

Reviews.Content: This camera was perfect! I have taken it to a concert and got amazing pictures.. I wasn't in nose bleed but I'm sure they still would have been great!! Perfect camera for beginner!!

Reviews.Title: not happy
Reviews.Author: Candee
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for events and travels. I go to a lot of events with my kids, concerts, parks,etc. and We also go to Disney a lot as well. I needed a camera that was low on the blur and good with video. As much as I research I can never find a camera that I am completely happy with. Not only does this camera takes blurry pictures (I guess my hand shakes) It takes really horrible video. While in Disney I was recording a parade, it kept going out of focus. I had to zoom in and out in order for it to focus back, plus it was grainy. I feel like I need to take a camera course, just to find a camera that can do all the things I need it to do correctly. I was really rooting for the Sony...oh well there $200 down the drain.
